bibl.title: Alfonso Gagliardi v. T.W. Lynch. Petition for Writ
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: In the Matter of the Application of Alfonso Gagliardi for Writ of Habeas Corpus.
TO THE HONORABLE JEREMIAH NETERER AND TO THE HONORABLE E. E. CUSHMAN, JUDGES OF THE ABOVE ENTITLED COURT:
Comes now the above named petitioner, Alfonso Gagliardi, by Clay Allen, his counsel, and respectfully shows to the Court:

The petitioner, Alfonso Gagliardi, is now and has been for some years last past a resident of the City of Seattle, King County, Washington, and is now within said division and district and within the jurisdiction of this Court.

The petitioner, Alfonso Gagliardi, was born in the City of Solofora, Province of Avellino, Italy, on the 30th day of April, 1898, a subject of the King of Italy, and has been heretofore and is now domiciled in the United States by and under and subject to the provisions of the Treaties existing between the King of Italy and the United States.

The petitioner first arrived in the United States on or about the 1st day of August, 1915, at the Port of New York in the State of New York,and proceeded directly from the City of New York to the City of Seattle within this division and district, and thereafter resided continuously in said City of Seattle, and parts adjacent thereto until the 4th day of November, 1920, at which time your petitioner returned for a temporary visit to Italy.

That prior to proceeding to Italy, your petitioner obtained from the Italian Consul his passport as an Italian Citizen, and proceeded to Italy with the intention and purpose of returning to the United States within a short period of time, to-wit: within a period of six months thereafter.

That upon attempting to return to the United States your petitioner was informed that the regular sailings to and from Italian Ports to immediate ports in the United States were filled for a period of some months, and upon inquiry at a Steamship Office petitioner was informed that he could proceed to the United States immediately by a ship sailing at a French Port and landing at a Canadian Port and thence proceeding by land to the Continental United States. That the passport

of your petitioner was taken from him by a person whom he was informed and believed was acting for the Steamship Company or in some Official capacity, and petitioner proceeded to a Port in France and thence to the City of Vancouver, British Columbia.

That on the 13th day of February, 1921, this petitioner, in company with his cousin, proceeded from the City of Vancouver, British Columbia, and passed through the Port of Entry at Blaine, Washington, and proceeded to the City of Seattle. That at the said city of Blaine, this petitioner submitted himself to examination by an individual, whom the petitioner alleges to have been an Immigration Inspector of and for the United States. That the petitioner advised him as to his place from which he came and the destination to which he was going, and this petitioner was upon this occasion admitted into the United States.

That thereafter, to-wit, your petitioner was on or about the 3rd day of October, 1921 arrested pursuant to a warrant, the same being No. 55162-17, and purporting to bear the signature of E.J. Henning, as Assistant Secretary of Labor of the United States, on a charge
"That he was likely to become a public charge at the time of his entry; and that he entered without inspection by means of false and misleading statements."
That thereafter at an examination held upon
October 21, 1921 before one Arthur J. Kahl,
Immigration Inspector of the United, States, an additional charge was lodged against your petitioner, as follows, to-wit:

"That you were unable at the time of entering the United States to read the English language or some other language or dialect including Hebrew and Yiddish although at that time over sixteen years of age and physically capable of reading and not exempted from the literacy test by any of the Provisions of Section 3 of the Immigration Act."

That this petitioner alleges that pursuant to said pretended Warrant of Authority, one Arthur J. Kahl, Immigration Inspector of the United States, at the City of Seattle, and T.W. Lynch, Acting Commissioner of Immigration, at the City of Seattle, and E.J. Henning, Assistant Secretary of Labor, have taken the body of your petitioner and caused him to be incarcerated and have threatened and are now threatening, by and under such pretended Warrant of Deportation and proceedings had thereunder, to transport petitioner from out this division and district and send him beyond the confines of the United States, and furhter alleges that unless said officers are restrained by this most Honorable Court, that the petitioner will be unlawfully transported from this division and district and without the confines of the United States.

The petitioner alleges that each and all the acts of the said officers of the United States are without legal form, warrant or authority. That the process issued herein is without legal authority, in that, at a hearing had pursuant to said alleged Warrant of Arrest, the said officers failed to adduce any evidence in support of the alleged charges made against this petitioner.

WHEREFORE your petitioner prays: (1) that citation issue out of this Court directed to the above named Arthur J. Kahl, Immigration Inspector of the United States, at the City of Seattle, and T.W. Lynch, Acting Commissioner of Immigration, at the City of Seattle, and E.J. Henning, Assistant Secretary of Labor, that they and each of them appear at a day fixed and certain and show cause why a Writ of Habeas Corpus should not issue out of this Honorable Court directing the release of the petitioner herein.

(2) That the Court direct the officers last named and each of them to set forth by affidavit or otherwise the evidence upon which their unlawful action is predicated, in that the Court may know that such proceedings are had as are in accordance with law.
(3) That a Writ of Habeas Corpus issue herein directed to the above named officers to
produce the body of your petitioner and upon hearing that this petitioner be discharged from custody.

ALFONSO GAGLIARDI, being first duly sworn on oath says: That he is the petitioner in the above entitled cause; that he has heard read the foregoing Petition for Writ, knows the contents thereof and believes the same to be true.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 13th day of December, 1921
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
In the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington
In the Matter of the Application of Alfonso Gagliardi for Writ of Habeas Corpus
Filed in the United States District Court
